direction.raw_text: The CAMERA now backs away from the scene into the BAR. (a section.) It backs to the back of the bar and proceeds -- in profile -- behind the backs of the barmen. A mixed crowd of people drinking before their lunch. We pick up the Doctor, leaning his head upon his hands, looking into space. The woman next to him, a noisy blonde, is laughing. The doctor glances up at her -- she glances at the doctor. She and the audience see the scarred side of his face -- the laugh dies on her lips and she turns suddenly to her companion, who is the Baron. We do not get much of a chance to see him because at that instant he is glancing at his watch, his shoulders are turning away from THE CAMERA and he moves out towards the lobby.

direction.raw_text: Near the conclusion of Kringelein's speech, we see the Doctor approaching through Kringelein's booth. He is looking down at something.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who is that, This is... Hello, hello!... Who is that... Heinrich? This is Kringelein. Hello, Heinrich. This is Otto Kringelein. Hello! Can you hear me?... I've got to speak very quickly. Every minute costs two marks ninety... What?... Otto Kringelein! Yes, I'm in Berlin, staying at the best hotel, the Grand Hotel... No, don't you understand? I want to explain, but I must do so quickly, it costs so much. Please don't interrupt me -- hello? Hello! Listen! You know that will I made before my operation? I gave it to you. I want you to tear it up. Destroy it. Because, listen, I came to Berlin to see a great specialist about that old trouble of mine... It's pretty bad, Heinrich. The specialist says I can't live much longer. (louder) I haven't long to live! That's what's the matter! Hello, hello. Are you on the line? No, it isn't nice to be told a thing like that. All sorts of things run through your head. I am going to stay here in Berlin. I am never coming back to Fredersdorf. Never! I want to get something out of life, too. You plague, and bother, and save -- and all of a sudden you are dead. Heinrich... You don't say anything. I am in the Grand Hotel, do you understand, the most expensive hotel in Berlin? I'm going to get a room here. The very best people stay here. Our big boss, Preysing, too. I saw him -- not five minutes after I was here. Sometime, I'd like to tell him exactly what I think of him. Listen, Heinrich -- I have taken all my savings; my life insurance, too; I cashed in all my policies, the sick benefit fund, the old age pension, the unemployment insurance, the burial fund and everything... What's that, miss?... Hello, Heinrich. I have to hang up now. I have to pay three times overcharge. Just think, Heinrich! There's music here all day long. And in the evening, they go around in full dress... Yes, sometimes I have pain, but I can stand it. Everything is frightfully expensive here. You can imagine, the Grand Hotel... What? Time's up...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you a minute now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- I told you not to come in this lobby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Time's getting short.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've told you a hundred times not to speak to me with a cigarette in your mouth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to speak -- BARON Not now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On another shot, shooting profile onto Senf's desk, bring in Flaemmchen. Flaemmchen enters. Her back to CAMERA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She crosses to elevator.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (we hear her ask) Mr. Preysing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you wait please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The stenographer is to go up -- Mr. Preysing telephoned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Preysing -- one sixty-four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks -- (calling off to elevator) Heigh! -- Wait!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . As she enters the elevator and the gate shuts, she turns around, back pressed against the Baron -- who is looking down at her. The look on her face is the look we often see on Flaemmchen's in elevators when they are pressed.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE CAMERA RUSHES UP BEHIND HER, ALMOST PUSHING INTO ELEVATOR WITH HER

direction.raw_text: : Good introduction, for Flaemmchen. The lift ascends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flaemmchen steps out of the lift. She is looking around for the numbers. She moves out of scene. The Doctor, Kringelein and the bellboy with the bag, move straight down the hall. Pimenov is chatting volubly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Flaemmchen being directed by the floor clerk to Mr. Preysing's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He proceeds up the passage, pompously, humming the air of his ballet. At that moment, Flaemmchen, who has been directed to Preysing's door, by floor clerk, passes the Baron and there is an amusing exchange of glances between them. Flaemmchen knocking at Preysing's door hears a voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She opens the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Baron) Poor Grusinskaya -- how can she receive anyone. She can't -- theatre, trains, hotels -- hotels, trains theatre.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) I must go and dress -- she'll be waking up and calling for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Preysing has had a bath and is actually steaming from it. He stands before a long mirror, rubbing himself with a towel. He sees her through the mirror, wraps the towel around him very cutely, for a big man, and turns upon her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is very much affronted. Flaemmchen, who has seen many large gentlemen in the altogether -- FLAEMMCHEN (lightly) Don't hurry -- take your time. She goes out of the room and shuts the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What...! -- FLAEMMCHEN I'm the stenographer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you will please wait outside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Flaemmchen emerges from Preysing's room. Baron loitering in the hall. (Whistling as outlined). Baron approaches, he is also whistling -- the same tune that Flaemmchen is whistling. She glances at him, as he continues whistling with an amusing dance step, as much as to say: "Are you mad?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baron glances back up the passage; it is apparent that he is going to make conversation here with this girl, in order to keep legitimately in the passage until Grusinskaya comes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances down the passage again, his hands in his pockets. She glances impatiently at her watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flaemmchen laughs at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At that moment we hear Kringelein's voice calling from his doorway at the end of the passage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Baron turns and looks off at --- KRINGELEIN Kringelein is in his door in the distance -- radiant. He waves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Like dancing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not with strangers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning to Flaemmchen) Never?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a fool!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I am rather.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He must be very nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gallantly) Whoever is keeping you waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating Preysing's door) Have you seen it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, my large and noisy neighbor -- really? That? (indicating Preysing's door)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with meaning) You?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Oh -- work!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with meaning) Oh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dictation. (she twittles her fingers) You know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... poor child. If you were free, I'd ask you to come and have some tea -- but -- FLAEMMCHEN Tea would spoil my dinner. (lightly) One meal a day, I'd hate to spoil it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Reducing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (she turns invitingly) No -- why? -- should I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lord no -- charming -- but why one meal a day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing in his face) Money -- Ever heard of it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- yes indeed -- but you are a... (moves fingers) ...a stenographer. Don't little stenographers earn little pennies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you ever see a stenographer with a decent frock on? -- One that she'd bought herself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Poor child -- (enthusiastically) I wish I were free tonight -- we could -- FLAEMMCHEN (with invitation) Aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Free -- BARON (glancing up passage) Unfortunately no -- to bad -- tomorrow though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow? What time tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shall we say five o'clock -- downstairs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where downstairs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yellow Room where they dance -- (business)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're very funny -- BARON (with great meaning) Yes? -- Tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll dance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) All right. We'll dance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Baron -- Oh, Baron!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I could trouble the Baron to come and see this beautiful room. I have ordered champagne. Perhaps the Baroness could join us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Waiter, oh waiter! Wait a minute! (to Baron and Flaemmchen) We are having caviar -- it's expensive but that makes no difference -- I see the Baroness is laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At that moment Grusinskaya's door opens suddenly and Suzette comes out into the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By this time the others are entering Kringelein's room. The Baron turns back for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette turns back into the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have caviar if you like, but it tastes like herring to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ssshh! Please! Madam is asleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling back quietly to Suzette) Asleep? -- Ssshhh -- sorry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is typical hotel. Half-open trunks, etc. Curtains are drawn -- room is in semi-darkness. There is a sense of silence, except for distant music coming from the Yellow Room below. In Suzette's hands we see one of Grusinskaya's ballet slippers which she has been mending. She is about to tiptoe to her seat when she stops suddenly and looks off dramatically at...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shot from her angle. She is sleeping beneath a Chinese robe, on the chaise-lounge. Apparently she has changed her position, because the hand which is outside the robe moves. The CAMERA, as though it were Suzette, moves up towards Grusinskaya. Her eyes are closed. Suzette crosses to the chaise-lounge and is looking down. Grusinskaya's eyes open suddenly. She looks at the ceiling and then her eyes turn and look straight at Suzette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like a soldier called to attention Grusinskaya sits suddenly upright -- GRUSINSKAYA Always the performance -- every day the performance -- time for the performance. (she pauses and droops suddenly) I think, Suzette, I have never been so tired in my life. (she takes the bottle of veronal which is nearby) Veronal didn't even help me to sleep. (laughs a little)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While she is speaking Grusinskaya rises -- with the grace of a dancer she picks up the Chinese robe that has fallen to the floor and although there is only one other woman in the room -- she holds the robe around her. She crosses to the mirror and looks at her face, running her fingers through her hair. She gently massages under her eyes and the CAMERA sees Grusinskaya for the first time. There is silence in the room -- neither of the women speak. Suzette gets madam's clothes ready. She crosses, puts the case of pearls down on the dressing table and opens them. Grusinskaya looks into space -- silence -- dead silence. Suzette kneels as if to put Madam's stockings on for her. Grusinskaya pulls her foot away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leans forward against the dressing-table and her hands unconsciously touch the pearls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She throws the pearls away, down upon the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette crosses replacing the pearls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grusinskaya's eyes are looking off into space -- she is away in Russia -- she does not look -- Telephone rings -- Suzette crosses to telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a knock at the door -- a certain kind of knock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She picks up the telephone and as she does so Pimenov enters. Suzette quickly gives Pimenov a signal that there is trouble. As Pimenov is closing the door we hear Grusinskaya speak into telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pimenov (at heart a clown) makes a grand comedy bow. He will deliberately try to tease Madam out of her mood. She glances at him, without smiling, crosses to the dressing- table and sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a hysterical out-burst. It is not a woman who is just temperamental, it is something deeper than that. She is very near a nervous breakdown. We, the audience, must feel with her a revulsion against the word performance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pimenov kneels by Grusinskaya -- he is chafing her hands, he attempts to soothe her. Now Grusinskaya draws her hands suddenly away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a sudden knocking at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens suddenly. Meierheim bursts into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Business of Pimenov signaling to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meierheim goes over to telephone, he picks up receiver and says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Show few feet of Grusinskaya getting dressed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly and reverently -- almost a whisper) Madam has slept well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I have been awake -- thinking -- thinking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is time for the performance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The performance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking into telephone) Madam Grusinskaya's car is to be brought.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't dance tonight -- SUZETTE It will pass -- it will pass -- come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let us cancel the engagement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But, Madam. cannot do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now is the time to cancel to stop entirely. I feel it -- everything tells me -- enough -- enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very quietly) The peals are cold -- everything is cold -- finished -- it seems so far away -- so threadbare -- the Russians -- St. Petersburg -- the Imperial Court -- the Grand Duke Sergei -- (long pause as though she were reliving incidents of the past)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sergei -- dead -- Grusinskaya -- it's all gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mon Dieu -- the pearls -- if they were to break -- GRUSINSKAYA The pearls won't break -- they hold together and bring me bad luck ---- I hate them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Orchids come again, Madam -- no card -- I think perhaps they are from the same young man -- he is at the end of the corridor -- tall -- he walks like a soldier -- Madam must have noticed how often he is in the elevator with us. Last night for instance -- GRUSINSKAYA Oh, Suzette -- Suzette -- Sshh -- quiet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, oui -- the car is here for Madam.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Send it away -- I shan't need it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (authoritatively) Madam Grusinskaya will not require her car -- no -- she will not be going to the theatre. (she turns)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is time for the performance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (under her breath) The performance -- the performance -- the performance. (during this scene the orchids fall to the floor)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tenderly -- as he touches her shoulder gently) Poor little Lisevata -- she still has her stage frights -- it will pass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is not stage fright -- it's something more -- PIMENOV (tenderly) What -- what is it? Last night...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Last night?... There was no applause.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) There was -- there was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That theatre -- half empty -- dancing for those few -- I was frantic -- I finished -- the last beat and... (she reclines her head as the swan finishing the dance) ...I waited -- I listened -- but the applause didn't come -- nothing. A man in the box -- and just the claques behind -- it is passed, Pimenov. We are dead -- it's finished.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Meierheim --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this that you have cancelled your car? Who am I that I should wait like a fool at the door? And here on a whim, you cancel your car. Have you forgotten there is a performance? Do you know the time? Or, are we all mad? Am I your manager?... Have we a contract? Have we obligations? Am I blind? (glances at his watch) ...Or is that the time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm cancelling the engagement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh! Madam is cancelling the engagement. Madam has chosen a funny time for such a funny joke. Ha, ha, ha -- hurry, come on. Tonight -- there's a line in front of the theatre since six o'clock. The house is jammed to the roof.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The house is not full -- Is it really full?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Packed to the ceiling. Hurry -- get dressed. And what an audience -- the French Ambassador -- American Millionaires -- Princess Ratzville -- er -- er -- GRUSINSKAYA (to Suzette) Oh -- but it can't be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, come, Madam -- please come. (she holds up her frock)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (changed mood) All right, Suzette -- quickly -- hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We will wait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are late. Hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell Madam Grusinskaya's chauffeur to bring the car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pimenov and Meierheim. Meierheim is pushing the bell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are walking towards Kringelein's room. They are pacing rather like men who walk the deck on a liner. They turn almost together, but when they turn back past the CAMERA the CAMERA PROCEEDS on into Kringelein's room. The CAMERA ENTERS THE ROOM to a burst of laughter. Champagne bottles open, caviar, smoke, etc. In the room are the Doctor, Kringelein, the Baron, Flaemmchen, and a very fat waiter -- comedian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Baron offers Flaemmchen a glass of champagne. She shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At that moment Preysing's voice is heard calling to the Floor Clerk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flaemmchen, hearing this, turns and looks off, apparently through the door. Her manner changes, she puts down her glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kringelein's optimism has left him for a moment, he stands looking out of door undecided, he is drooped suddenly, as though years had returned to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start to leave. Oh, gentlemen, please don't go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baron leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They move into the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How is the house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terrible. After this, no more ballets for me. Jazz -- (snaps his fingers) Just jazz.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If the house is empty again, I don't know -- MEIERHEIM When she gets her paint on and hears the music -- she'll be all right. I know these people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You may laugh. Caviar and champagne may mean nothing to you, but to me -- they mean a great deal. You see, I'm ill and all of a sudden I got a fear of missing life. I don't want to miss life -- do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are funny. You speak of life as if it were a train you wanted to catch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- and for me, it's going to leave at any minute. Let's drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure this beautiful room must appeal to your taste -- distinctive, don't you think? Velvet upholstery -- 'A-number one'. I'm in the textile trade and I know. (he has a slight case of hiccups from the champagne. He touches the drapes) And these are real silk drapes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amusedly) Silk -- think of that -- silk -- they are, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (who hasn't stopped talking) Have you seen the bathroom? -- Hot and cold running water -- You see, I can get a bath whenever I like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The stenographer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her master's voice! (turns to Baron) I must go now -- goodbye -- thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, don't go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm engaged for the evening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, can anyone engage you for the evening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To take dictation -- a Mr. Preysing -- (to Baron) Goodbye, you -- tomorrow at five o'clock. (she is moving out)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter, Mr. Kringelein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) General Director Preysing! (possibly he turns to Baron) Baron, when I was sixteen years old, I started as an office boy in that man's factory -- BARON Then you know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do I know him -- I know him through and through.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must -- I hope to see you again, Mr. Kringelein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will stay, Doctor -- if you have nothing better to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have nothing better to do, Mr. Kringelein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : 24 and 25 Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pimenov and Meierheim are standing there. Meierheim is pushing the elevator button. The Baron stands near and pauses, he is now a changed man. He looks off as he hears the voice of Grusinskaya, off in the distance. Grusinskaya's Voice Hurry, Suzette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shot from the Baron's angle. Grusinskaya is sweeping down the corridor, followed by Suzette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps you could present me now, Mr. Pimenov.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grusinskaya sweeps into scene. The Baron leans forward quickly and pushes the bell with a glance at her. They look at each other. He fixes his eyes on her characteristically. She glances at him. This is the first time they have met in the picture. She is impatient. As if to break an awkward silence, she turns to Suzette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette is carrying the coat over the pearls. As she takes the coat off her arm, Grusinskaya glances down at the jewel case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette toddles off with the pearls. The elevator opens, collects its passengers, all except the Baron and descends.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Baron -- forgive me -- not now -- here she is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My coat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Suzette -- I told you not to bring the pearls. I will not wear them tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take them back, Suzette.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You haven't time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hurry, Suzette.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Such nonsense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A shot of Grusinskaya's eyes as she goes down, glancing up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shot of the reverse of him looking down. The Baron pauses, hesitates, thinks. We are interested in his action. For the first time he becomes furtive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FROM ELEVATORS Music swells up from the Yellow Room. A great deal of noise, confusion and activity as the elevator stops to emit Grusinskaya, followed by Pimenov, Meierheim and some other people who are rather excited to be in the elevator with the great Grusinskaya.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bellboy hears it and passes the word around. It seems to be echoed through the lobby. People turn, as Grusinskaya's spirit seems to rise with the attention she is getting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off scene) The car for Madam Grusinskaya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: precedes her through the revolving door, as she sweeps outside of the hotel. The Baron's chauffeur, Schweinke, is seen to watch her go. He looks furtively around and enters the hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CLOSEUP OF BARON As he watches Suzette returning from Grusinskaya's room. She is about to push lift button - then decides to run downstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zinnowitz and Preysing are standing by door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zinnowitz leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No news from Manchester yet -- Do you think we ought to postpone the conference?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good heavens no. That'd create the very worst impression. You must be optimistic. You must convince them. You know as well as I do that the merger must go through.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- the merger must go through -- But I am used to making my deals on a solid basis. I am not a liar. I am an honest business man -- a good husband and father -- I have a sense of honor -- I have nothing to conceal. I couldn't live happily otherwise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, don't get excited about it. We agreed that the merger with the Saxonia people must go through.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to dictate my statement for tomorrow. I can't speak without notes. I like to have things down before me in black and white.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see you in the morning then, at the conference. Everything'll be all right, Preysing... Don't worry. Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We hear the distant voice of Preysing and the keys of the typewriter rattling. The reason for the blackness is that Preysing's back is flat into the camera. His hands are behind his back and his fat fingers are moving restlessly. It is an odd effect. We don't know quite what it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Preysing moves forward showing that we are in Preysing's room. The change of light shows us plainly the time lapse. Flaemmchen is seated at a small table typing. Preying strides forward As he strides he says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Preysing paces the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During this, Flaemmchen, who is tired sits back and rubs her fingers that have been over-worked. She glances at her wrist- watch. Preysing comes and stands behind Flaemmchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he turns, he catches a down shot on her from behind as she stretches back showing her busts. Seeing his face looking down on her she pulls herself together and seats herself at attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It seems a silly kind of lull.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him, waits a moment and then begins characteristically to, change the sheet of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Baron peeps out onto balcony -- it seems to be clear. He proceeds along and peeps into Preysing's room. Preysing is apparently in the bathroom. Baron skips nimbly past the room. Working at thrill of pass through to Grusinskaya's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baron is pretty shaken by jump.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darkness -- light from transom and building opposite. Business of finding key and getting pearls. INTERCUT Preysing coming out onto his balcony, bringing out with him, loud speaker of radio -- which announces noisily as follows:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: 'You are listening to the music of the Eastman Jazz Band, in the famous Yellow Room of the Grand Hotel.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Baron starts suddenly -- when he hears voice and with pearls in his hand, looks cautiously out of window -- only to see:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ONTO PREYSING'S BALCONY: Preysing seating himself upon his balcony -- Radio loud speaker seen. Possibly Preysing commences dinner scene bullying waiter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Baron knows he is trapped, if he jumps onto Preysing's balcony, Preysing is the man that will cause the alarm. Quickly he moves across the room -- tries the door -- it is locked securely. He looks for skeleton key and then remembers refusing it from the chauffeur. He is trapped in an absurd way. As he moves back from the door, he knocks the telephone off of the table. He watches it for a moment, realizing that the operator must now know that there is someone in Grusinskaya's room. He picks up the telephone, replaces the receiver, wipes finger prints off with his handkerchief. He is moving back to window when telephone starts to ring suddenly. The thought crosses his mind they they will want to know who is in the room. He lets the telephone ring. Crosses to the door again. Above the din of the telephone we hear the chambermaid's voice singing an absurd song. He listens. She is coming in. The key turns in the door. Quickly he hides behind the curtains. Slowly and amusingly the chambermaid, tired and dragging, enters the room. He is looking for an opportunity to dash through the door. After all, this maid should be an easy person to get around. We have a feeling he wishes to dash through the door. The chambermaid might be singing the same tune that we hear from Preysing's radio. The telephone commences ringing. Chambermaid does not answer it but continues her duties. At last, because of the noise of the telephone, she picks it up and speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At that moment, the Inspectress, a large stout woman, appears at the open door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Inspectress, in a very businesslike way, proceeds around the room, coming nearer and nearer the Baron. She is looking at ashtrays and running her fingers over the woodwork looking for dust. She tries the door to the next room, to see if it is locked. Telephone bell rings again. Inspectress picks it up quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, out of scene, we hear the voice of Suzette. Suzette is calling out to the night clerk in the passage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette comes in and hurries to telephone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No -- no -- there is no one here. (she replaces the receiver)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Chambermaid) You're late... What have you been doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grumbling) Everyone -- all the time says, 'Come back - come back.' They won't get out of their rooms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Madame Grusinskaya is not here... The Western Theater?... No...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you seen Madame?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (replying) Isn't she at the theatre?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, hello, Mr. Pimenov? Yes... Mr. Pimenov, have they found her?... No, she is not here... Yes, I'm at the hotel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: With the Baron watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During this action the Inspectress has waven the chambermaid out of the room. Business ad lib. Meierheim enters, he has heard the word 'Pimenov' on the telephone -- he takes the receiver from Suzette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and sees Grusinskaya standing at the door. She is in costume, very pale, very beautiful. Her coat, over one shoulder, is ragging, she lets it drop and moves slowly into the center of the room. Her hair, dressed for the dance, make-up is on her face -- she is breathless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other women in the room draw out, leaving Suzette to pick up the robe that has fallen to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette obediently crosses to door and pauses on threshold, waiting for Meierheim. Meierheim approaches Grusinskaya.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette, with a frightened look through the door, closes it on Meierheim's exit.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into telephone) Pimenov?... What's happening?... No, I haven't found her. Is Desprez dancing?... How is it?... Oh, all right. Keep the show going. (bangs down receiver) Wait till I see her, she'll pay for this -- this little trick is going to cost Grusinskaya a suit for breach of contract.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madame is ill -- her nerves...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her nerves... What about my nerves?... Who is she anyway? Where does she think she is -- Russia? Those days have passed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madame -- MEIERHEIM Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to be alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where have you been?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should I -- Does madame wish...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Suzette, please go, I want to be alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose I can cancel the Vienna engagement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish to be alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll be very much alone, my dear madame. This is the end. (he stamps out)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S OF BARON. It is some time before Grusinskaya moves. She crosses to door -- turns the key -- takes the key out of the lock and throws it away from her -- out upon the floor. She crosses slowly to the mirror, regards herself, silently. We hear the strains from Preysing's radio playing a light Viennese waltz. Grusinskaya begins suddenly to sob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watching her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quite suddenly -- as if with resolution she begins to undress. Then she becomes weary again. With a garment in her hand, she moves slowly toward the curtain -- where the Baron is standing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see him tense himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She drops the garment listlessly to the floor -- moves out of scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He peeps around the curtains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is in a thin robe. She sits before mirror -- looks steadily at her face. Her head goes down suddenly in her hands and we hear her say:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly she moves quickly across the room. Goes to bathroom. Baron half starts out toward door. He watches -- darts across the room as if towards the door. He hears her coming and darts quickly into the half open door of the closet. She re-enters -- carrying a glass of water. She crosses, places the glass down beside the bed -- her movements are quick and furtive -- then she crosses, picks up the telephone -- asks for the theatre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leaves receiver down -- crosses quickly to mirror -- stands there and brushes back her hair -- crosses back to telephone speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She glances up at the clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again she puts the receiver down -- picking up a pencil she commences hastily to scribble a note. She writes frantically. Her other hand goes up and picks up the receiver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She finishes the note -- commences suddenly to speak into the telephone -- GRUSINSKAYA Hello, Pimenov? -- I'm at the hotel. I couldn't go on -- I couldn't... No, no don't -- (long pause) ...Just alone... Good night, good night, my dear -- goodbye... Pimenov, how is it going, badly?... Uh?... Who's dancing?... Desprez?... Oh -- and how is it?... Oh, -- oh, I see -- they didn't miss me?... They didn't miss me. (she lets her hand drop with the receiver and goes on talking into the air) They didn't miss me -- good night, Pimenov... She is about to replace the receiver. She sits with it in her hand, unreplaced. The music has stopped. The room is strangely silent. Behind her the Baron peers from the closet. Her head sinks down upon her hands. A funny, singing noise comes from the telephone. She lifts the receiver to her ear. In a very strange voice, the voice of Opehlia, she speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The foregoing scene is much better played than described. It is in fact, ballet. Quite calmly, Grusinskaya finishes the notes on the table. She folds it up and places it in a prominent place on the table, or hangs it over the telephone. She crosses to the window pulls back the curtains -- the Baron has been hiding behind a few minutes before. We see the Baron watching. He glances at the door quickly. "No, there is not time." She is returning calmly. She crosses to the dressing table and takes the veronal out of a drawer. She looks at it thoughtfully, her lips are trembling a little. She moves to the radiator as if to seek warmth. She sinks into a chair and her head droops over her folded hands which contain the veronal, she seems to pray. The Baron comes from the closet -- now is his chance, he looks at the door but can't make it. Looks on the floor for the key which Grusinskaya has previously thrown there, his eyes fall upon the note on the telephone -- he reads it. It is a death farewell note to Suzette -- do not insert it. At this moment she has finished, the Baron returns to his hiding place. She makes the sign of a cross and goes to her bed. She looks around nervously, apprehensively -- like a deer who has heard something, then reassured. She places the veronal on the night table beside the glass of water. She is quiet and deliberate. She arranges the pillows under her head and lies down. She reaches for the bottle of veronal and empties it generously in her hand. She has to lean away upon one elbow, from the Baron's position, in order to balance herself. The Baron steps like a cat from his hiding place. He goes to the bedside noiselessly and stands there. She reaches for the glass-her hand stretches out for the glass. The Baron takes her wrist suddenly. She turns quickly looking at him. The glass falls to the floor with a crash and breaks. As she moves, the veronal falls out of her hands upon the bed. She struggles up to a sitting position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She glances up at him. She is bewildered. She seems to be coming out of a trance. Again she wants to jump from the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now she becomes conscious of almost nakedness. She draws her kimono tightly around her, glances across the wide expanse of bed. We see her consider passing over that way, but she is now a woman again -- a woman of the earth -- it would be a silly movement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets up quickly and crosses, putting on her robe which was lying across the back of a chair. Her first movement is not one of alarm but of -- shame. She draws her robe more closely around her and looks at the Baron puzzled. She thinks, dreamily, "What is this?" She glances back at the veronal and the bed showing us plainly that this man must have watched her preparation for bed. We get a sense of relief with her. She is trembling. The Baron has controlled his nerves perfectly. He senses his danger. He is caught red-handed with five hundred thousand marks worth of pearls in his pocket. He is wondering if she will ring the bell. For an instant he thinks of escape. He could dash for the balcony. He could strike her dead or silence her with threats. There is in the room an intoxicating sense of romance and danger. (It should be in the scene.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him for a few moments and then suddenly she throws herself upon the bed and begins to weep more and more passionately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A look in his eyes reminds her of the strangeness of the situation. She rises with returning dignity and pulls her robe around her -- she is becoming the Grusinskaya of Imperial Russia; she is the woman Grand Dukes have fought for. She sweeps across the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets her cigarette box from the writing table and holds it out to him. He takes a cigarette and lights it. She watches him curiously. She smiles, as she watches him greedily inhale the smoke. She crosses and sits before her looking glass. She brushes her hair back and powders her face. She looks into the mirror, we feel that she has regained a desire to live. He crosses and looks at her in the mirror. He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outside the distant noise of Kringelein is heard -- BARON What? Say it again -- I didn't hear. She whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The way she says it, the word goes home. It hurts him. She has looked into his eyes for a moment with a strangely melting and almost happy expression. She gets up suddenly. (NOTE: The other side of the bed -- not where the glass is) She reaches with her feet for her slippers. She puts one on. She can't find the other. Business as he gets other slipper for her. He kisses her ankle and looks up at her. She smiles down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He watches her. The sound of her own voice reassures her. She is generating warmth. Her cry has done her good, she speaks quickly, volubly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grusinskaya turns, she is graceful again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She rises. She had expected something else. His reply strikes her as chivalrous and considerate. She crosses to the writing table brings back her little cigarette box which she holds out to him. He takes a cigarette and lights it. She watches him curiously. She smiles, as she watches him greedily inhale the smoke. She crosses and sits before her looking glass. She brushes her hair back and powders her face. She looks into the mirror, we feel that she has regained a desire to live. He crosses and looks at her in the mirror, he smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly he stoops, takes her shoulder in his hands and kisses it. A long tender and sincere embrace. Her eyes close. A tremor passes through her. Suddenly his whole being is aware of her. She turns, rises and disengages herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances back. He speaks suddenly with an air of command.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her head falls slowly on his breast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He crosses quickly to her and holds her in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outside the distant noise of Kringelein and the doctor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The end -- over -- finished --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Western Theatre --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Western Theatre?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The stage -- Mr. Pimonov -- the ballet master... Grusinskaya -- hurry -- hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- yes, I'm waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with great humility) Oh -- I'm sorry, yes... I have finished. (she replaces the receiver)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, do not be alarmed, Madam.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Careful -- there's broken glass on the floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There. (takes a pillow from the bed throws it upon the floor over the glass, steps back)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please do not be frightened, Madam.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a silence) What do you want here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing -- only to be here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you hide in my room?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But surely you must know -- because I love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because you love me -- you love me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going over to her) Poor little Grusinskaya! Does it do you good to cry? Are you afraid? Shall I go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was so alone -- always alone -- and suddenly you were there and said that. (sitting up) No. I am not afraid. It is strange.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't cry -- it tears my heart to see you sob like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (regaining control) Nerves -- just nerves. You must forgive me. I have had a bad evening. I am very tired. Do you know what it is to be tired -- tired of a routine existence?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid not -- I usually do just what I feel like doing at the moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you feel like coming into a lady's room -- and you come... What now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (following her) I'd like to smoke a cigarette.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you look at me like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did not know you were so beautiful... and -- GRUSINSKAYA (bitterly) And then --?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No irony. You're so appealing -- so soft -- so tired. I feel like taking you in my arms and not letting anything more happen to you -- ever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (involuntarily closing her eyes) And -- and -- BARON How tired you are!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: approaching the CAMERA with the Doctor. They are returning from the bar and are passing Grusinskaya's room. THE CAMERA precedes them. The Doctor is characteristically drunk. He is silent, tense, cynical. A distinct contrast to Kringelein, whose soul is warmed for the first time by alcohol. Kringelein's hat, the same, eccentric one, is twisted upon his head jauntily. The carnation is in his buttonhole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: backs into Kringelein's room and pauses, because the Doctor has paused at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the Doctor has gone. Kringelein re-enters his beautiful room. He crosses to the mirror, regards himself. Business ad lib. He looks at himself in the mirror and raises his hat. Imitating the doctor, he repeats:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts his hat on the knob of the bed. He takes off his coat, holds it up and carefully takes the carnation out of his buttonhole. With the coat over his arm and the carnation in his hand he looks around for a glass and some water which he sees standing on the night table by his bed. He puts the carnation in the glass, having filled it with water and then his eyes fall upon his small group of medicine bottles. His demeanor changes. He immediately becomes a thing of pain. He glances at his watch -- it is long past his medicine time -- his spirit droops -- he might almost be in pain. He picks up a small bottle and carefully counts eight drops into the glass. He is about to take it, he smells it, a sudden impulse of well-being surges over him. He flings the medicine away. With a great wave of optimism he commences to sing the song that we have heard during the evening -- the chambermaid song - the Preysing radio song -- the love song. He saunters around the room, undressing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, but Doctor. Isn't this wonderful. To live -- to live -- in the Grand Hotel.

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition was in my blood -- no rest, no stopping. We were drilled like little soldiers -- We danced in the school of the Imperial Ballet, in St. Petersburg. I was little and slim but hard as diamond -- a duty machine -- No rest, no stopping. And then -- I became famous and whoever is famous is alone... But why should I be telling you this? Last night I did not know you at all -- who are you, really? -- I do not even know your name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My mother called me Flix.

By the business of the Baron, although we do not of course know it, this is the time that he takes the wallet from Kringelein and puts it in his own pocket. We might perhaps remember a sudden turn away in which we see his back and his right hand raised as though reaching in his inside pocket -- He stands looking down at Kringelein.

direction.raw_text: The foregoing speech is intercut with the following action in which Kringelein's voice is heard throughout -- thus it is not a long speech: The Baron watches. He throws his cigarette away -- he bites his lip -- sweat breaks out upon his forehead; again he is a thief. When he wanted pearls the love of a woman stopped him. Now he wants this money and pity, a slow growing pity for this tragic, dying thing is stopping him -- and all the time the Doctor watches. The one, whole eye pierces into the Baron's melting conscience. Twice during the speech at a spot, through and during rehearsal, to be selected, the Doctor's voice, droning but piercing, says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These are two interjections. And now, Kringelein lies upon the floor, a troubled little sack of pain, his head down. The Baron turns away. He bends down as though he were looking for the pocketbook. We see him take it from his pocket and turn. There is a very light, almost triumphant ring in his voice as he says:
