dialogue.raw_text: (mutteringly) I'd like to live a little longer but -- I'm not afraid to die -- I'm not...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (touching his shoulder gently) You'll be all right, Kringelein. (he moves from the bed -- takes out a cigarette, moves to the table. He seizes his drink)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (out of scene) My pocketbook... my money in it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you say -- what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You what -- Oh, isn't it there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- But no I -- Baron, I've lost my pocketbook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is no pocketbook here... On the floor probably. (He glances down)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (starting up suddenly) More than fourteen thousand marks... were in that pocketbook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at Baron) Fourteen thousand marks... One can travel -- one's happiness might depend on fourteen thousand marks -- don't you think so, Baron?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a shrug) Quite possibly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I've got to find it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay where you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- I must find it -- (he starts talking) Fourteen thousand two hundred marks. (he pulls himself to the side of the bed)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm all right, Doctor. There's no pain now -- only you don't know what that money means to a man like me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (talking at intervals as he crawls looking for money) You don't know, because you've never lived like a dog -- in a hole -- and saved and scrimped. My life hangs upon that money, Baron. Nobody gives you anything. You have to buy everything and pay cash for it. I wanted to pay for my last days with that money. Every hour costs money. I've nothing -- nothing but that pocketbook. (he crawls along the floor on his hands and knees talking to the carpet as he looks) I must have it back. (he pauses breathless -- like an animal along the wall -- looking up at the men)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He must find his money, Baron. (next time) Mr. Kringelein should find his pocketbook, Baron, shouldn't he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here -- here it is. Here's your pocketbook, Kringelein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his head coming up) Oh -- yes -- that's it -- you found it -- you found it for me, Baron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Goodnight, Kringelein. (he moves towards the door.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- no please -- oh, don't go -- don't go -- don't leave me alone, Baron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've nothing to fear, Kringelein
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come, get up -- come let me help you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : If he is a strong actor he can pick Kringelein up -- If not, he and Doctor lift Kringelein to bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baron bites his lip. It is the first and only time in the play that we see a tear near -- the strong man almost breaks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're all right now -- it's very late -- goodnight, Kringelein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no, stay here, Baron -- stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight, Baron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight. (his hand presses on Kringelein's shoulder -- he exits)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Baron shuts door and pauses. In front of him is the door of the woman he loves. Down beyond is his own empty room. In his pockets nothing. In his CLOSEUP he makes the audience feel his problem with him. This man who has lived and whistled and love through the play becomes a tragic, lonely, harrassed figure. The Baron has broken. His fists dig into his eyes -- he brushes his hair back. Over this comes with almost an impertinence, a tiny whistle. He looks up and away down the corridor. The figure of Flaemmchen stands there, a small black bag in her hand. The Baron pulls himself together and smiles characteristically. He walks down the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both go into their respective rooms. Here are our two gay young characters. The gay, fresh Flaemmchen and the debonair Baron, crucified for lack of funds. Both trying to smile, both trying to be light about themselves. Yet, each about to involve themselves tragically for the want of a little money.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Flaemmchen, what are you doing here in the middle of the night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looking for my room -- one sixty- six.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You live here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For tonight. (she points to door -- she looks at him a long time)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- oh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- such is life, Flaemmchen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Baron, thanks so much for everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Flaemmchen enters her room cautiously. Except for one lamp burning the room is in darkness and empty. From the adjoining door to Preysing's room a thin stream of light. She puts down her bag quickly, tiptoes through the bathroom to his door. She peeps through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: from her angle. Preysing stretched on bed flat, his stomach a mountain and on it the magazine that he has been reading with Flaemmchen's picture. He is looking at the ceiling. She knows he is awake because a thin stream of smoke comes from his cigar in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An idea occurs to her. She could possibly sneak into bed and he would go to sleep and there would be nothing that night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as she tiptoes to her room. She closes the door noiselessly and listens. She throws off her hat and takes off her coat. Opens her bag and takes out night dress, lingerie, etc. The lid of her bag falls suddenly. She starts at the noise. "Has it awakened him." She looks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The thin stream of light is filled suddenly, the door of the adjoining room opens and back-lighted from the other room the huge form of Preysing appears. In this odd lighting he is a little more than Preysing. He comes forward. He speaks hoarsely, quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes to his arms passively. He rubs his face in her hair. She is passive -- cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds her again, trying to kiss her. She deliberately avoids his kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Preysing rises while she pulls her night dress from under him. He draws her to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Preysing laughs. She laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a pause for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flaemmchen yawns straight in his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves towards the windows which are open. She pushes his fat body out, almost playfully, through the doors and onto the balcony. Preysing stands out on the balcony. He looks down in the street below, then off. He starts suddenly because he sees a shadow over the railing of his own balcony. He is puzzled. Shadow crosses again. "Who can be in his room?" He moves forward and peeps through the window. One side of the French window is closed. From his angle we see the Baron furtively searching the room. He is now wearing an overcoat, the collar is turned up. Business ad lib. He finds Preysing's wallet. He stuffs this in his overcoat pocket. Preysing's face watching him. As Baron turns to exit, Preysing surges forward, pulling the window after him. The two men face each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Baron hands him the pocketbook without a word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Baron makes for the door on the other side of the room, pulls at the knob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Baron makes one dive across the room. Preysing grasps at his coat and tears it. With one hand holding the telephone, (the receiver dropping on its cord towards the ground) and one hand holding the Baron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Preysing wrenches the telephone suddenly away from the Baron. The action excites him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a terrific lunge, Preysing brings the telephone down upon the Baron's head. The Baron sways, stunned. (as in book). In his mad rage, Preysing, hits again with the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By this time the Baron is a heap on the floor. We see Preysing come out of his blind trance. He even repeats again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Flaemmchen! (he seizes her to him)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (breathlessly) You are late. I've been waiting for you -- waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had to arrange about the trip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're sweet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (awkwardly) Come here. (he sits heavily on the bed, sitting on her night dress.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, hold up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- careful, Mr. Preysing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call me -- do you know -- would you -- would you like to call me by my first name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling away, glad of an excuse for conversation) Oh, no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't do that, you're a stranger to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a funny little creature, Flaemmchen. I can't make you out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not funny at all. One can't get intimate just off hand. I could go to England with you and everything like that -- supposing I met you next year and I said: 'How do you do, Mr. Preysing! And you said: (she imitates him) 'That was the young lady who was my secretary in Manchester'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all quite proper. (she is happy again. She would rather talk than be squeezed) But supposing I met you when you were with your wife and I called out: "Hello you big baby -- remember Manchester?' And you with your wife, how would you like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Flaemmchen -- we'll leave my wife out of this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. I'll get undressed -- get out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aha! -- The Baron. What do you want here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must have made a mistake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Made a mistake -- remarkable. We shall soon see if you made a mistake. (the Baron starts to leave.) (bellowing) Stay here... Give me that money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So that's how we stand, Baron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look here, sir -- I'm completely at your mercy -- I'm desperate -- it's a matter of life or death -- I had to get some money -- tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indeed you must, Baron -- you must. Humm -- humm, but you must go to jail, Baron, you're a thief.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be quiet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to call the police. I'm going to watch you play the great Baron with the police. Aristocrat! Aristocrat! (he picks up the telephone)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The door is locked, Baron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into telephone) Hello! Hello! -- BARON Don't do that. (he tries to snatch the telephone from Preysing.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Strike me, would you? Attack me would you? Attack me --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll strike you -- I'll strike you -- I'll strike you -- Strike me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I strike you -- (with telephone foolishly in his hand, he looks down at what he has done.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sharp sound of buzzing. Dozing night girl plugs in, lazily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With nonchalance she flicks plug out again, as she does so:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- yes -- Operator -- Operator -- (she listens -- says to herself) They are having a nice little game up there with the telephone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: New angle. Preysing is on his feet. He has replaced the receiver on the telephone, he is putting it back slowly. He is terrified. Door opens behind him. Flaemmchen, with a dressing gown on, light, filmy thing, crosses and looks down at the Baron, without a word. Preysing seizes her. Her hand goes to her head, her eyes roll; for a moment we think she is going to faint right on top of the Baron. She is trying to collect her senses, it cannot be true. We can hear nothing but the heavy breathing of Preysing and the traffic below. Suddenly a motor horn in the street below sounds strident, it is the first time we have been conscious of it. With a swift movement, Flaemmchen dashes towards the door. It is locked. She rushes back as if to cut through her own room. He reaches for her and rips her dressing gown from her, leaving her almost naked. He lunges after her. She tears through her own room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flaemmchen enters from her room. She looks this way and that. After all, it is Flaemmchen and not Lillian Gish, running across the ice in "Way Down East," -- it is Flaemmchen, a Berlin girl. She pauses to try and clear her brain. "What the hell is this -- what is it." The impulse naturally is to scream in alarm. She doesn't -- Flaemmchen's don't. She looks around. At the end of the passage is Kringelein's room. She will go there. We watch her run down the passage uncertainly. Without knocking she pushes open Kringelein's door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is in darkness. The only light comes through the windows. The form of Kringelein lies prone upon the bed, the Doctor had just thrown a coat over him. He is still in his trousers and shirt. Like a ghost, Flaemmchen, the shreds of her filmy clothes hanging to her, crosses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sweeps to bed. She shakes him. Kringelein starts up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pulls on the light by the bed, it flames up on their faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It occurs to him that this girl with her torn clothes must have been roughly treated by Preysing. He suddenly assumes a strength.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slides down to the floor, by the side of the bed. Kringelein climbs out of bed, tries to help her up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She waves him away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kringelein assumes suddenly a strength. He is a man for a crisis -- he forgets that he was ever ill -- he leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (hoarse whisper) Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Kringelein -- where are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quick -- Mr. Kringelein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- what -- what -- (he is looking up at what seems to be a ghost.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- oh, Miss Flaemmchen. It's you -- FLAEMMCHEN Quick -- something awful -- awful has happened. Go -- go at once, -- Mr. Preysing -- KRINGELEIN Preysing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, don't wait -- go -- it's awful -- it's awful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't wait now -- go -- Preysing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CUT HIM DOWN CORRIDOR QUICKLY. He pauses outside Preysing's door, uncertain of the rooms, then he knocks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He feels there must be a mistake -- he steps back, sees Flaemmchen's door open next to it. He enters.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Mr. Preysing -- Oh, Mr. Preysing --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He enters. Looks around. Looks through bathroom. Goes quickly forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Preysing is still leaning against the table, his mouth is open, he is gaping -- stunned. The two hundred and four pounds has collapsed and sagged. He is staring, his victim lying -- a heap upon the floor, very still and quiet. His eyes come around as Kringelein enters. Kringelein crosses, looks down. Touches the Baron's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Preysing takes him by the shoulders.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- the Baron -- the Baron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He tried to rob me -- he is dead -- KRINGELEIN My best friend -- poor, Baron -- dead -- just like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must do something...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Yes, the police must be called.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- no -- wait -- the man was a burglar -- he was going to steal my money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no -- no -- not the Baron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly) Where is that girl -- she was working with him -- she enticed me into her room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her room -- oh -- I see, Mr. Preysing -- I understand, Mr. General Director Preysing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frantically) I can answer for this, it was self- defense -- I can answer for this -- but that girl -- the scandal -- my wife -- my daughters, you know them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I know them -- PREYSING The scandal -- we are men -- you -- you could take that affair of the young lady upon yourself -- take her and hold your tongue. Then you can travel -- I'll give you anything -- anything -- she was with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must call the police, your excellency.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much -- how much do you want -- you need money -- you have nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry about me, Mr. General Director Pryesing -- worry about yourself. (he picks up receiver) There has been a murder -- this is room one sixty-four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Telephone girl plugs in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello -- hurry up... hurry up... someone in one sixty-four says there has been a murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The scene gradually grows intense. Porter calls night man.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here - quick - here -- go to one sixty-four immediately. (calls back on telephone) Give me Mr. Rohna -- Rohna the manager.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Darkened room. Bell ringing. Rohna sits up in bed, turns on light, picks up telephone; on his face we see him hear the news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (he replaces the telephone commences dressing quickly)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where?... murder?... who?... all right, I'm coming. Wait a minute. (speaks in a monotone) Instruct everyone to use the utmost tact -- we must have no scandal in the Grand Hotel. Answer no questions, I'm coming now -- inform the police.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Trunks standing around everywhere. Suzette is finishing packing. Grusinskaya is sitting in front of the mirror in a loose night wrap -- she is doing her hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette leaves -- turning out a light. Alone, Grusinskaya goes to the telephone. She raises the receiver.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Madam should sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've done my hair differently -- do you like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When a lady falls in love she does her hair differently.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) In the middle of the night -- those flowers make me think of a funeral. Laurels and tube-roses. (she pushes the window closed, shivers, it is chilly. She crosses the room turning out one of the lights) Oh, think, Suzette -- the Villa and the sun at Tremezzo -- quiet -- simple -- happy -- we'll have a guest, Suzette.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Yes, Madam. And now Madam will sleep. It is not long 'till the train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight, Suzette.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello -- can you tell me if Baron von Gaigern is in his room -- ring him. (talking to herself) Cherie, I must wake you or you'll miss the train. (into phone) ...yes... are you ringing, he may be asleep. (to herself) Cherie, you must get up and fetch me from my room -- I'm longing for you, Cherie -- I have not been to sleep -- I kept thinking you would come to me. (into phone) ...Oh, but he must answer. Ring -- ring -- ring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: at discretion the:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Telephone is ringing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to herself) Cherie, hurry -- hurry -- hurry. Answer the phone -- what is the matter. (into phone) Ring him -- ring him. (to herself) Where are you -- where are you, Cherie? Why don't you answer? (into phone) Well, ring him -- please -- please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Music up as we -- FADE IN ON:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR SERVICE ENTRANCE OF HOTEL The trees and the milk cart effect and other curious signs of dawn, which we remember after the climax of the first sequence. Music cold and eerie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : General early morning bustle and activity. From one van, fruit and vegetables are being unloaded. From another, huge hind quarters of beef are being carried in and in a monotonous way a baker throws two loaves at a time, to another man, from a van backed up -- BAKER (counting) Forty-two -- forty-four -- forty-six -- forty-eight -- fifty -- fifty-two -- Waiters coming to work. A noisy racket. Sandwiched between the bread and butcher vans, is backed a hearse. At the moment we come upon it, the men are pausing in their work to glance. The men take off their caps, as; proceeded by the hotel detective and others, who will be there, the corpse of the Baron in the basket, used at such time, is brought out and placed in the hearse, which drives noisily away. A policeman rides with the driver on the box. By this time the man with the bread is counting: BAKER One hundred and eight -- one hundred and ten -- one hundred and twelve... Stay with him for a moment. DISSOLVE OUT:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR FRONT OF HOTEL Shooting onto door - day lighting. A man comes out and signals a black closed limousine, which pulls forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MAIN HOTEL LOBBY Early morning. Sense of chill and desolation. Some chairs stand on tables. A vacuum cleaner is at work on the carpets. Newspaper boys are delivering papers at the news stand. The various shops are slowly being opened, the windows being cleaned. The general feeling of the beginning of another day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: waits at a distance shooting from door as Preysing, with a plain clothes man on either side of him, leaves, moving towards THE CAMERA. He is grim, his hat is drawn over his eyes. His hands deep in his pockets. When he has passed the CAMERA MOVES FORWARD TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (the old shot) Meierheim is entering quickly goes through the door. He crosses now to Pimenov. They talk eagerly out of earshot. But it is apparent that Meierheim is, as usual, in a hurry. Rohna is there too. One of the men carries a telephone stand, wrapped loosely in paper. But we know it's the telephone stand. Senf comes on duty, looks around, it is apparent that he is late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A number of bellboys march up and form a line. Senf comes from behind the desk and inspects them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They show their hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys sit down on the bench.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The night clerk has already gone -- you are late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Man -- I was at the clinic the whole night -- there are no words to describe what my wife suffered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the child isn't coming?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- no -- not yet. Well, I mustn't let it interfere with my duty. Any news here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: News? Yes -- killing in number one- sixty-four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? -- Who? -- Whom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The big manufacturer killed Baron von Gaigern.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good heavens. What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Man -- that's terrible. He was a nice fellow -- I am sorry about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It seems that he was a thief and an imposter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't believe it -- he was a real gentleman. I know people... I'm so tired I can hardly see out of my eyes. No sleep for two nights and so many duties and now this killing in the hotel -- that means a lot of work. But it's too bad about the Baron, you always felt better when he came along -- always friendly -- such an agreeable fellow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Most imposters are --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in chorus) Good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show your hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to one boy) You have dirty nails -- you little pig -- you're no good... Caps off! -- Let's see your hair. (Boys take off their caps) Good -- caps on! (Boys put on their caps) Where is number seven?... Not here? (to clerk) Take his name -- if he comes late again today, he's fired. Dismissed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Kringelein and the police officer move towards the desk in ear shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kringelein exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please, officer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That will be sufficient for the present, sir, you may travel in peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Kringelein emerges from the elevator, Suzette speaking to the Floor Clerk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette hurries down corridor. By this time Kringelein has arrived at his door, he opens it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And they've taken him away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- it's terrible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madam must not know -- you understand -- Madam must not know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will tell the maids. I cannot answer for downstairs --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kringelein opens the door and enters. Flaemmchen is looking into space. A lovely picture. Morning light over her hair, she is dressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kringelein straightens, happy, inspired, a smile on his face. He assumes in his gestures. Takes the telephone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- I was thinking -- Poor Baron -- Lying there, his eyes so open.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You loved the Baron, didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- KRINGELEIN So did I. He was friendly to me as no man ever was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps he really was a burglar -- But they don't kill a man for that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was in desperate straits. He'd been trying to raise money all day. He laughed -- Poor devil! And then a man like Preysing kills him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (naively) I didn't like Preysing right off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why did you have anything to do with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (simply) Money!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course, -- money!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't understand that do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I do -- I never knew what money really meant till I started spending it. Do you know -- (he is silent a moment) I can hardly believe that anything so beautiful should come to me from Preysing -- I'll take care of you. Will -- will you let me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll have a good time with me. Want to? I've got enough money. Ten thousand two hundred in my pocketbook. Three thousand four hundred that I won. It will last a long time. I can win more -- we'll travel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- to Paris? I wanted to go there always.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wherever you like. Here I'll give you the money I won, three thousand four hundred. Later you can have more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Later?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I -- I'm ill, Flaemmchen -- It will not be long -- I'll not last long. Will you stay with me until...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nonsense! We'll find a great doctor, he'll cure you. They can cure anything these days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you believe that you will have a better time with me than you would with Preysing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes, of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (takes her hands) Do you like me better?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a good man, Mr. Kringelein -- a very good man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into telephone) When is the next train leaving for Paris? -- Yes... Get two tickets for me... and my bill please... and the lady's -- Miss Flaemm's. (puts down telephone) (to Flaemmchen) We have to hurry let's pack -- we'll have breakfast on the train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The figure of Grusinskaya is standing at her door, there is no one with her. Suzette steps out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Madam, it is Mr. Meierheim -- he is waiting downstairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is Pimenov? Where is Pimenov? (she looks off.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: coming out of the elevator. Grusinskaya hurries down to Pimenov -- they meet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She crosses and looks in the Baron's room. A maid is there changing the bedding. The room is unoccupied otherwise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The maid nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maid shrugs her shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While they are waiting for the elevator Grusinskaya is like a live electric wire. The elevator arrives. They are stepping in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (breathlessly) He will be on the train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But when did he go? How do you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Baron von Gaigern has left?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When? How long ago?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Baron left about half an hour ago, Madam.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- Gru -- come, come -- we'll lose the train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: General activity. We hear the cry go up:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grusinskaya comes out of the elevator followed by Suzette and Pimenov. Meierheim meets her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grusinskaya crosses to the desk. She speaks to Senf.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grusinskaya, followed by the others, sweeps out towards the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Madam Grusinskaya's car...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come along, oh, Madam, come along. The train will be going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute. I've got to ask myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the use of asking, Gru -- he is at the train -- He will be there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The troupe, the scenery, everything -- all on board, waiting. You have a rehearsal in Vienna tomorrow morning. Come, Madam, are you mad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you seen Baron von Gaigern?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (comes over quickly) The Baron is not here, Madam.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is gone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Madam.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four minutes past. Please come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come, Lisaveta, he will be there -- he will be there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Madam Grusinskaya's car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Grusinskaya emerges, followed by the others. The sunlight hits them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grusinskaya moves forward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, the sun -- it will be sunny in Tremezzo -- MEIERHEIM Every seat for the opening has been sold at Vienna. Sold out for three days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know -- I know -- but it will be sunny in Tremezzo. We'll have a guest then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (knowingly) Yes, Madam.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madam Grusinskaya's car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (at telephone) Grand Hotel, Head Porter. What? There's been -- a child born? A boy! Yes! My child born! It is healthy... and my wife? Doing well -- all well! (to Clerk) The child has come. They are both alive. My child...
direction.name: direction
